In the wake of the Chinese central bank’s decision to ban initial coin offerings (ICOs), which sent Bitcoin tumbling despite the agency’s announcement making no specific mention of it or any other cryptocurrency, we thought it reasonable to introduce our new Refresher feature with a breakdown of the latest method of raising capital, specifically as it relates to the venture capital ecosystem.

An ICO differentiates itself from other methods of fundraising insofar as investors receive virtual tokens as opposed to traditional shares for their investment. The tokens, which are offered only by the company, increase in value as a company or network proves its viability and boosts liquidity, thereby attracting interest from other investors. ICOs tend to be issued by companies with little more than a blueprint of a business model, which, combined with the fact that some have provided returns multiple times the original investment, has resulted in some analysts seeing a massive amount of speculation beyond the practice. The SEC has indicated that ICOs could be considered securities and therefore fall within its purview but has not taken further steps towards regulation beyond requiring the transactions to be reported. The agencies skittishness regarding the investment model is understandable, as ICOs have raised $1.6B over the last year alone, and, as CNBC reports, have now surpassed early-stage VC funding.

TechCrunch has reported that two companies, OmiseGo and Qtum, have already reached unicorn status following ICOs occurring in July and March respectively. Interestingly, neither company has yet to offer an actual product. This raises the question as to what unicorn status will mean for these companies, given that it has arguably functioned mostly as a status symbol in the VC world, in addition to offering companies publicity to attract new customers and investor interest. On top of this, having a unicorn in a firm’s portfolio was a mark of a VC’s prowess, even more so when the investment was made during an early-stage round. What does a unicorn entail when it only represents a massive sum of liquid capital?

If it turns out to mean a lot, one can understand a recent Founder Collective piece that began by framing ICOs as an existential threat to venture capital. The author effectively made the argument that the accessibility and liquidity offered by cryptocurrency, combined with the mentioned possibility of a 10x upside (the return on OmiseGo’s coins bought at the ICO stage comes in at 40x), has the possibility to disrupt the industry providing capital to the companies who have historically provided disruption. Irony aside, assuming VCs will react to this by protecting their firms, it is pertinent to ask the question as to whether (early-stage) investors should be allowed to participate in token sales, especially when considering issues of transparency and self-serving motivations. Furthermore, as Flybridge’s Jess Bussgang asks, if VC firms start buying into the plethora of new cryptocurrencies becoming available, how will this be different than purchasing fiat currencies; to what extent would this put VCs in competition with hedge funds or cryptocurrency hedge funds; what will VC funds’ LPs think of this sort of practice? What this boils down to is: will VC firms be forced to fundamentally alter their investment models in order to accommodate the new tastes of entrepreneurs? If not, will startups that bypassed early-stage fundings turn around and contact VC firms for their series B and beyond?

This largely depends upon the fallout for companies that opt to eschew traditional private funding for ICOs, which largely remains to be seen as the companies themselves are still so young. Cooperation between an experienced VC and an ambitious founder has shown itself to be a combination hard to compete with, and as such, the prospect of founders answering to a slew of possibly impatient investors lacking in foresight seems a little hazardous. The first stages of growing a fledgling company require a steady hand, and the ability to know which early hits to take for bigger gains later. Moreover, the network provided by the right VC can very well be the factor that makes or breaks a company, and it certainly doesn’t seem like token holders will be able to offer the same sort of connections. Even if ICOs offer infant companies the capital they want, it doesn’t fill the gap that traditional VC has in the last years with regards to honing a company’s model, focusing them on the raison d’etre of their product, and otherwise discipling them/letting them loose at the right moments.

As promised, today we're presenting our AMA session with Jason Calacanis, CEO of Inside and successful angel investor. This is a special feature for premium subscribers who help support Inside Venture Capital.
Here are just a few of the questions we received:
If you only have $1000 a year to invest, is it worth using sites like Seedinvest to invest in two companies a year?
What are your thoughts on ICOs as an alternative funding mechanism?
How would you recommend a recent MBA grad with a tech background get into Venture Capital?
Since we got so many great questions, we're breaking Jason's answers into two parts. Below is part one; look for an email with part two next week.

--VC Reads--
-- Finding the Right Price for Early Customers: Ash Rust, Sterling Road’s managing partner, delves into one of the most difficult dilemmas for young startups.
-- Not obvious. Never Easy. Does happen.: Rory Stirling, partner at BGF Ventures, gives the pitch decks from YouTube, LinkedIn, and AirBnB.
-- “We have a common philosophy that it all starts with people” — Heather Hartnett on Human Ventures, NYC’s Startup Studio: Homebrew’s Hunter Walk interviews.
-- A computer was asked to predict which start-ups would be successful. The results were astonishing
-- Floyd Mayweather Just Joined the ICO ‘Coin’ Craze: Fortune reports.
--VC Reads--

-- What you need to know before raising a Micro-VC fund today: Angel Investor Samir Kaji notes that fundraising cycles have not gotten shorter, the experience gap difference of LPs’ managers, and more.

-- How To Sell The Problem Before Selling The Solution: David Bailey of Downing Ventures discusses the intricacies of creating demand, including how to determine target audience, niche, key activity, and more.
-- How Retail Can Thrive in a World Without Stores: The Harvard Business Review discusses advances made in creating the sensation of personal touch in online venues.
-- Jessica Livingston on What’s Different about “Unicorns”: The YC founding partners speaks at the Female Founders Conference. (Video)
-- SoftBank is reportedly keen to buy ‘multi-billion dollar stake’ in Uber: TechCrunch reports on WSJ sources, notably less than 24 hours after Grab’s $2B raise was announced.
--VC Reads--
-- Why I’m Not Investing in Your Startup: Li Jian, investor at GSV Capital, gives us three of many reasons.
-- Breaking (Bad) Mantras: Rodrigo Martinez of Point Nine Capital praises taking risks and being contrarian as the basis of exception investments.
-- Startups in Southeast Asia vs. MENA: United we stand, divided we fall: Enis Hulli of 500 Startups reveals a dynamic that doesn’t usually receive much press.
-- A running list of every company backed by the $93B SoftBank Vision Fund: TechCrunch reports.
-- Google.org is launching a $50 million effort to prepare job seekers for the ‘future of work’: Recode reports.
-- Slack is raising a $250 million round at $5 billion valuation: TechCrunch reports that the round included SoftBank and Accel.
--VC Reads--
-- How to Build a Great Tech Company That VCs Will Love: MobileMonkey’s Larry Kim talks to Pillar VC’s Sarah Hodges on hot areas, successful companies, and more.
-- The Death of “Alternative Energy”: Andrew Beebe, investor at Obvious Ventures, discusses the word’s etymology and explains why no one can truly justify fossil fuels.
-- Several departures at venture firm Kleiner Perkins: TechCrunch reports that general partner Mike Abbott has left, and an early-stage team has been shuttered.
-- 500 Startups shuts down its Canada fund: TechCrunch reports that the move is due to the wake of the sexual harassment allegations against Dave McClure.
-- Apple, Google Drop Trading Apps After Australian Intervention: Bloomberg notes that the apps were accused of operating beyond the reach of regulators.
--VC Reads--
-- Even Smart VCs Invest in Cross-Industry Clones: Enis Hulli, associate partner at 500 Startups, argues for a somewhat more conservative strategy of scaling disruption across markets.
-- I Only Have 7 Trips Left. On Managing Work / Life Balance, Love & Family: Mark Suster discusses thinking about the future and growing into maturity.
-- Creation and consumption: Benedict Evans of Andreessen Horowitz claims that PCs are the no longer the vehicle of creation, and have been supplanted by tablets and mobile.
-- WTF is PMF? (part 1 of 2): Christoph Janz, managing partner at Point Nine Capital, discusses product/market fit.
-- A Private Equity Fund Formerly Valued at $2 Billion Is Now ‘Nearly Worthless’: Fortune reports on the decline of EnerVest.
-- Can the Tech Giants Be Stopped?: The Wall Street Journal chronicles the rise, and wonders whether there will be a fall.
--VC Reads--
-- Questions Worth Asking: Bryce Roberts discusses the implications of his faith for his profession.
-- Amidst probe of alleged sexual misconduct, AngelList partner Lee Jacobs on leave: TechCrunch reports.
-- Do VCs Need A Conduct Board For Sexual Harassment?: Takeaways from panels at Fortune’s Brainstorm Tech conference.
-- Women Are Better at Crowdfunding Than Men Are. This is Why: Fortune discusses the use of the emotional appeal.
--VC Reads--
-- The Decline Of Investment In San Francisco Startups: Tomasz Tunguz, VC at Redpoint Ventures, notes that, depending on the series, funding rounds in SF peaked in 2013-2015.
-- The Creation Story of Women in VC: Union Square Ventures’ GM Bethany Marz Crystal discusses herding male VCs as the only woman in the room.
-- The system for labeling fundraising rounds is broken and useless: Mattermark co-founder Andy Sparks offers a critique of the “alphabetical investment round labeling system.”
-- Three Questions Founders Should Ask VC Scouts Before Taking An Investment: Homebrew’s Hunter Walk discusses the increasingly popular funding practice confronting startups.
-- 15+ Ways a Venture Capitalist Says “No”: Robbie Allen, founder at Automated Insights, translates the sometimes cryptic and dishonest ways VCs let down or string along young firms.
-- SoftBank's Son Finally Explains How All Those Deals Fit Together: Bloomberg reports.
-- Tech Is No Bubble, But the Stock Market Might Be: The Wall Street Journal offers some mixed news.

--VC Reads--

-- Why Is Innovation So F*cking Difficult?: Investor in AI at Permutation Ventures Riva-Melissa Tez illustrates how buzzwords and strict indicators have a corrupting influence on engineers' creativity in a hypothetical story.
-- How Do I Feel About the Snap IPO Given I Didn’t Invest?: Mark Suster talks about his decision to not invest in Snap, and why he’s ok with it.
-- If You Don’t Know How Much You Need the Default is Always “More”: Bryce Roberts on why the next round is always the goal, and why it may behoove us to hone in on what we really want.
-- Chinese Game Site Said to Seek Funds at $1.2 Billion Valuation: Bloomberg on the reports of Douyu’s plans to raise $145M to expand beyond game-streaming and defend its market share.
-- With Snap’s I.P.O., Los Angeles Prepares to Embrace New Tech Millionaires: The NYT profiles how the real estate, lawyers, wealth managers and the employees are planning for the windfall.

-- How Tech Policies May Evolve Under Republicans and Trump: A NYT interview with Senator John Thune, who leads the commerce committee, on net neutrality, zero rating, privacy, driverless cars, and more
--VC Reads--
-- Why VC’s are obsessed with large outcomes: Fred Destin, Partner at Accel, explains the math that results in the need to push for the biggest returns.
-- The Five Truths I Learned as an Early-Stage Investor: Shuly Galili, co-founder of UpWest Labs, on the need to get scrappy, the unavoidability of personal problems, building data, and more.
-- How to land an Associate job in VC: Lightspeed Venture Partners’ Alex Taussig starts by asking his readers if they even want the job, and then telling them to figure out their superpower.

-- Obamacare launched a new wave of start-ups. Now they’re bracing for what’s next.: The WP profiles some of the affected startups and their problems, and digs into how large the ripples could be in the tech ecosystem.
-- Brand Boys: How An Upstart Private-Equity Firm Makes 40% A Year On Gourmet Jerky And Vegan Makeup: Forbes profiles Alliance Consumer Growth and their take on building consumer brands.
-- The Alternative Facts of Cable Companies: Backchannel details the possible implications of NY Attorney General Eric Schneiderman’s decision to sue Spectrum for misleading customers.
-- Airbnb’s Surprising Path to Y Combinator: Backchannel profiles the company’s resurrection from almost certain demise.
--VC Reads--

-- Understanding Abundance, part 2: Silicon Valley’s Special Sauce: Alex Danco, from Social Capital’s Discover Team, breaks down the ability of the tech industry to satisfy consumer’s unquenchable desire to consumer.
-- 55 Things I learned as a 19 Year Old VC: Tiffany Zhong talks about spending her first years after high school working as an analyst at Binary Capital, how she got there, and moving forward.
-- Introducing Fika Ventures - a $40M Seed Fund: Partner Tianxiang Zhuo dishes on the latest addition to the Bay Area and LA’s tech funding landscape, and their plans to infiltrate NYC and Seattle.

-- Employees Referral Programs are Killing Diversity in the Tech Industry: BPI France Director of Development Alexandre Kaykac notes that 50% of SV employees are referred, and argues that this is stunting the industry at large.
-- Amid global uncertainty, startups aim to hire and see opportunities in 2017: Silicon Valley Bank offers an optimistic worldview, including a prediction of more IPOs, in its Startup Outlook 2017.
-- Office Hours with Kat Manalac: The YC partners talks about bringing incubators to local scenes, targeting customer base, self-inflicted failure, and more. (Video)

-- One Reason Staffers Quit Google's Car Project? The Company Paid Them So Much: Bloomberg investigates how big payouts created financial security for employees that allowed them a greater ability to leave.
-- Craigslist Is Ugly, Janky, Old School…and Unbeatable: Backchannel asks why the anti-business model has served the site so well, and ponders why its hands-off approach is so popular with users.
-- Europe’s Tech Sector Shrugs Off Regional Uncertainty: The NYT looks into Europe’s bullish tech market and it’s more tempered mentality on funding.
--VC Reads--

-- Birth of an Ecosystem: Understanding the Market for Black and Latino Tech Consumers: 500 Startups partner Monique Woodard points to demographic and income shifts to argue for paying more attention to technologically underserved American minority members.

-- 2017 YC Annual Letter: Sam Altman announces the expectation for YC startups to jointly surpass a valuation of $100B, and looks both forward and back on topics such as diversity, hyperscale, and others.

-- Financial Modeling For Startups: The Spreadsheet That Made Us Profitable: Launch platform Startups.co shares the spreadsheet they inherited from Carao Ventures, shares which sections they have cut, and explains the importance of those that they have retained.

-- Fred Wilson and Andy Weissman Talk with Lindel Eakman about Transitioning Leadership at a VC Fund: The Union Square Ventures founder talks together his successor and Foundry Group Next director at the Upfront Summit.

-- 20VC with Founder Collective’s Managing Partner Micah Rosenbloom: Topics include de-emphasizing top line valuations, the need for capital efficiency for return and investment success, and the virtue of a $100M exit. (Podcast)

-- 33 VOICES: A Talent Handbook for Startup Founders: Beth Scheer (Head of Talent at Homebrew), Katie Hughes (Talent Partner at DFJ) and Prateek Alsi (Partner at General Catalyst) talk diversity in tech. (Podcast)
-- Uber Gives Restless Employees a Way to Cash Out: Bloomberg profiles a little known share buyback system, and uses it to dig into the dynamics of startup equity in general.

-- Challenger Banks in Europe: Frontline Ventures B2B Seed investor Thomas Olszewski breaks down the impetus for the EU’s fastest growing fintech sector, and what regulatory hurdles it might have yet to face.
-- Tech Jobs Took a Big Hit Last Year: Fortune gives us the numbers, noting particularly that tech layoffs jumped 21% and accounted for 18% of all US job cuts.
--VC Reads--
-- 55 things learned as a 19 year old VC: Tiffany Zhong joined Binary Capital as an analyst at age 18 – and she shares a massive wealth of learnings from her time there.

-- Nano-Venture Funds are All the Rage: Samir Kaji, managing director at First Republic Bank, defines nano-ventures as seed-stage funds of less than $15M, and explains why they’ve become so attractive.
-- Make Price the Last Thing: Techstars founder David Cohen uses the intuitive logic of sales to explain why startups need to leave price to the end of their pitch.

-- On Intentional Work, Level Ventures, and What I’m Investing In: Level Ventures startup founder Sari Azout uses mandated bed rest to expound on what it means to juggle a VC firm and a family, and more.
-- Katie Dill on High Resolution: Airbnb’s Director of Experience Design discusses framing user experience through lived interaction, and more. (Video)
-- Wells Fargo Pushes Into Artificial Intelligence: Fortune writes on the bank’s decision to form an AI team, what it hopes to accomplish, and its place in a larger movement.
-- Asian Tech Titans Take a Page From Trump’s Book: The NYT looks into the announcements by Alibaba’s and Foxconn’s founders, and others, to invest in the US.
-- Time to Stop Acting Like Lemmings: TechCrunch looks into the history of tech IPOs and tried to figure out where they all went.
--Consumer Internet--
-- Shansong (Beijing, China), same-city courier platform: $50M C led by SIG Asia, Yi Capital, participation from Prometheus Capital.

-- bloomon (Amsterdam, Netherlands), online subscription flower delivery service : $23M B from Fortino Capital, INKEF Capital, Partech Ventures, angels. Founder Patrick Hurenkamp established and managed Rocket Internet’s Benelux outpost.

-- TravelTriangle (Charlottesville, VA/India), online holiday search and booking platform: $10M B led by RB Investments, participation from SAIF, Bessemer. Plans expansion into travel agency management tools.

-- Shop.co (San Francisco, CA/Germany), multi-platform e-commerce unified checkout cart: $7M Seed from Sparkasse, NRW, The Boston Consulting Group, Fabian Thylmann, Panya Putsathit, et al. To prepare for US product launch.
--Biotech/Health--
-- Prexton Therapeutics (Geneva, Switzerland), treatment of central nervous system conditions: $31M B led by Forbion Capital Partners, Seroba Life Sciences, participation from Merck, Ysios, Sunstone.
-- Chondiral Therapeutics (Bala Cynwyd, PA), treatments for rare mitochondrial diseases: $22.6M A from Deerfield Management.

-- Comprehend Systems (Redwood City, CA), clinical trial acceleration and quality improvement: $15M C from  Eminence Capital/ Sequoia Capital, Lightspeed Venture Partners. CEO Rick Morrison is a part-time partner with Y Combinator.
-- Verato (McLean, VA), identity matching for patient analytics: $12.5M B led by Bessemer Ventures, Columbia Capital.
-- Ceres Nanosciences (Manassas, VA), nanoparticle biofluid sampling: $3M A led by GreyBird Ventures.
--Industry4.0--

-- Desktop Metal (Burlington, MA), metal 3D printing for the industrial process: $45M C from GV, BMW i Ventures, Lowe's Ventures. CEO Ric Fulop founded six companies including electric car battery manufacturer A123 Systems, in addition to spending five years as a partner at North Bridge.
--Agtech--

-- TerrAvion (San Leandro, CA), drone-based early detection system for irrigation and plant health issues: $10M A led by Merus Capital, participation from Promus, Initialized, 10x Group. Plans to expand in Great Plains, Mississippi Delta, Pacific Northwest.
--Fintech--
-- Bloom (Leawood, KS), robo-advisor for US retirement account investing: $9.15M B led by QED, Commerce Ventures, participation from Allianz Life, Nationwide, TTV, KCRise, Industry, UMB.
--AI/Machine Learning--

-- Integrate.ai (Toronto, CA), combines corporate customer data with consumer internet data: $5M Seed from Georgian Partners. CEO Steve Irvine has two other startups under his belt, in addition to heading Facebook’s Marketing Partners Program and Instagram’s Partner Program.
--AR/VR--

-- SubVRsive (Austin, TX), VR experiences for film and branded content: $4M A from WPP, et al. Newly-appointed CEO Johannes Larcher has two successful exits via acquisition to his credit, and is an Angel investor with Capital Factory.
--Adtech/Martech--
-- Brandzooka (Boulder, CO), video ad targeting and slot purchasing platform for SMEs: $1.5M from Batshit Crazy Ventures.
--Edtech--
-- CodeMonkey (New York, NY), online programming game for children ages 9 and up: $1.5M Seed led by J21 Corporation, participation from Invictus Capital, Education VC Fund, Edulab.
